description:
Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare, commonly known as common barley or cultivated barley, is a subspecies of the cereal grain Hordeum vulgare. It is a major crop plant that has been widely cultivated for thousands of years, primarily for its edible seeds (grains) that are used in various food and beverage products.

Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare is an annual grass that typically grows to a height of 60-120 cm. It has a slender, erect stem with narrow, linear leaves. The inflorescence is a dense, terminal spike-like cluster of spikelets, each containing one or more florets that develop into the barley grains.

The grains of Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare are typically oblong or cylindrical in shape, with a hard, tough outer husk (hull) that can be difficult to remove. The grains can vary in color from pale yellow to dark brown, depending on the cultivar.

Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare is widely cultivated in temperate regions around the world, and it is an important cereal crop that provides food, animal feed, and is used in the production of malt for beer and other alcoholic beverages.
